Issues.Title: feat(compiler): Recover on malformed keyed reads and keyed writes
Issues.Body:
This patch adds support for recovering well-formed (and near-complete)
ASTs for semantically malformed keyed reads and keyed writes. See the
added tests for details on the types of semantics we can now recover;
in particular, notice that some assumptions are made about the form of
a keyed read/write intended by a user. For example, in the malformed
expression `a[1 + = 2`, we assume that the user meant to write a binary
expression for the key of `a`, and assign that key the value `2`. In
particular, we now parse this as `a[1 + <empty expression>] = 2`. There
are some different interpretations that can be made here, but I think
this is reasonable.

The actual changes in the parser code are fairly minimal (a nice
surprise!); the biggest addition is a `writeContext` that marks whether
the `=` operator can serve as a recovery point after error detection.

Part of #38596

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): API for getting components from a template file
Issues.Body:
This commit adds an API to `NgCompiler`, a method called
`getComponentsWithTemplateFile`. Given a filesystem path to an external
template file, it retrieves a `Set` (actually a `ReadonlySet`) of component
declarations which are using this template. In most cases, this will only be
a single component.

This information is easily determined by the compiler during analysis, but
is hard for a lot of Angular tooling (e.g. the language service) to infer
independently. Therefore, it makes sense to expose this as a compiler API.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler-cli): API for getting components from a template file" (#39002)

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): hybrid visitor returns parent node of BoundAttribute
Issues.Body:
For the following example, the cursor is between `keySpan` and `valueSpan`
of the `BoundAttribute`.
```html
<test-cmp [foo]Â¦="bar"></test-cmp>
```
Our hybrid visitor will return `Element`in this case, which is the parent
node of the `BoundAttribute`.
This is because we only look at the `keySpan` and `valueSpan`, and not
the source span. The last element in the AST path is `Element`, so it gets
returned.

In this PR, I propose fixing this by adding a sentinel value `undefined`
to the AST path to signal that we've found a source span but the cursor is
neither in the key span nor the value span.

Issues.Title: fix(docs-infra): fix the `component-interaction` example to run in prod mode
Issues.Body:
Previously, the `component-interaction` docs example was configured to run e2e tests on CI in dev mode (in contrast to the default for all docs examples, which is to run e2e tests in production mode). The reason was the following:
- One of the components, the `CountdownTimerComponent` component, which is used by the `CountdownLocalVarParentComponent` components and the `CountdownViewChildParentComponent` component, was triggering a periodic asynchronous task (via `setInterval()`), which prevented the app from stabilizing and caused tests to fail.
- In order to prevent this from happening, the example's `AppModule` had special provisioning to not include the problematic components in its declarations when testing.
- Since this had to be determined dynamically at runtime (via inspecting the URL query params), the `AppModule`'s config could not be statically determined in AOT compilation.

This commit fixes the example to make it compatible with AOT compilation and removes the custom test-command from its `example-config.json` (allowing it to be run with the default e2e test command in production mode).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(docs-infra): fix the `component-interaction` example to run in prod mode" (#38994)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): Add keySpan to bindings in the TCB
Issues.Body:
The `keySpan` is needed as a way to distinguish inputs of microsyntax
bindings because they will all have the same sourceSpan:

```
var _t1 = _ctor();
_t1.ngForOf = something /**sourceSpan*/
_t1.ngForTrackBy = trackByFn /**sourceSpan*/
```

By adding the `keySpan` to the left hand side of the assignment, we can
use that to identify the correct node in the TCB, given a
`BoundAttribute`.

Also note that this produces diagnostics that are more in line with what
TypeScript would produce. We now will produce a diagnostic that points
to the key instead of the whole assignment statement, just like
TypeScript would do in the following example:
```
let a: {age: number} = {} as any;
a.age = 'laksjdf';
^^^^^ <-- Type 'string' is not assignable to type 'number'.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler): Add keySpan to bindings in the TCB" (#39000)

Issues.Title: i18n ID generation should ignore inner HTML tag attributes and interpolation content
Issues.Body:
# ð feature request

### Relevant Package
- @angular/core
- i18n

### Description
Let's imagine the following snippet:
```html
<button i18n="...">
  <icon value="notebook"></icon>
  Edit {{ 1 + 1 // i18n(ph="number") }}
</button>
```

The generated message would _look like_:
`[ICON_TAG_START][ICON_TAG_END] Edit [NUMBER]`

Therefore if I modify the icon `value` to say... "pencil", I expect my localization not to be affected, however at this time, Angular i18n considers _all_ the inner HTML contents to generate, this means that `<icon value="notebook"></icon>` is used to generate the ID when it doesn't actually (in most cases) affect localization.

_The same is true for interpolation._ For example, If I change `{{ 1 + 1 // i18n(ph="number") }}` to `{{1+1 // i18n(ph="number")}}`, where the contents didn't even change semantics, the whitespaces just got removed.

**Note:**
This is slightly related to the Issue about whitespaces such as indentation affecting localization
Issue: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/13114

### Describe the solution you'd like
As stated above, I would like that Angular would generate the localization ID based of a normalized string instead of the inner HTML.

The normalized string would mean:
- whitespace is normalized (unrelated to this report, but still important)
- transform inner HTML tags into the respective placeholder (e.g. `<icon></icon>` -> `[ICON_START][ICON_END]`)
- transform interpolation to the respective placeholders (e.g. `{{ 1 + 1 }}` -> `[INTERPOLATION]`)

**And then** generate the ID based off this:
`[ICON_TAG_START][ICON_TAG_END] Edit [NUMBER]`

Not based of the inner HTML character by character.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Sometimes it's possible to alleviate these issues with `<ng-container>` such as:
```html
<button>
  <icon value="notebook"></icon>
  <ng-container i18n="...">Edit {{ 1 + 1 // i18n(ph="number") }}</ng-container>
</button>
```
However this is not always ideal because some non-English languages may change meaning slightly based on this difference.

For example this is **not** localization-friendly:
```html
<button>
  <icon value="notebook"></icon>
  <ng-container i18n="...">Edit</ng-container> {{ 1 + 1 // i18n(ph="number") }}
</button>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "i18n ID generation should ignore inner HTML tag attributes and interpolation content" (#38980)

Issues.Title: refactor(http): remove most of the typescript overloads and infer the response from the options instead
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [ ] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [x] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [x] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?

Return types for common/http are done via overloads which results in complex code completion. And not all valid values are immediately obvious.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/905328/94295103-0c360980-ff61-11ea-9d95-6d49084f7355.png)

## What is the new behavior?

Return type is inferred from options, so the method signature stays lean

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/905328/94294988-e4df3c80-ff60-11ea-92b5-7682c5caf95f.png)

My intention was to keep all prior defaults intact so this is not a breaking change - e.g. if prior infer was `any`, it stays `any`. If it was `Object` (with a capital O?), it stays `Object`.

Also trying to get rid of the not very helpful ~15 overloads below each method on https://angular.io/api/common/http/HttpClient

All methods (apart from `request`) now look like

```typescript
  post<R = Object, O extends HttpRequestOptions = object>(url: string, body: any, options?: O):
      Observable<InferHttpResponse<O, R>> {
    return this.request<any>('POST', url, addBody(options || {}, body));
  }
```

where `InferHttpResponse<O, R>` infers the response type from the options and wraps it accordingly.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(http): remove most of the typescript overloads and infer the response from the options instead" (#38999)

Issues.Title: test(compiler): add tests for parsing of malformed property reads
Issues.Body:
The expression parser already has support for recovering on malformed
property reads, but did not have tests describing the recovered ast in
such cases. This commit adds tests to demonstrate such cases; in
particular, the recovered ast is a full PropertyRead but with an empty
property name. This is likely the most preferred option, as it does not
constrain consumers of the AST to what the property name should look
like. Furthermore, we cannot mark the property name as empty in any
other way (e.g. an EmptyExpr) because the property name, as of present,
is a string field rather than an AST itself.

Note that tokens past a malformed property read are not preserved in the
AST (for example in `foo.1234`, `1234` is not preserved in the AST).
This is because the extra tokens do not belong to the singular
expression created by the property read, and there is not a meaningful
way to interpret a secondary expression in a single parsed expression.

Part of #38596

Issues.Title: Form status is not correctly propagated in the nested CVA forms
Issues.Body:
<!--ððððððððððððððððððððððððððððððð

Oh hi there! ð

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

ððððððððððððððððððððððððððððððððð-->


# ð bug report

### Affected Package
```
"@angular/animations": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/common": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/compiler": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/core": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/forms": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/platform-browser": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^10.0.9",
"@angular/router": "^10.0.9",
```

### Is this a regression?
No, I don't think so, it's also reproducible in Angular 9.

### Description

I'm not sure if it's a bug but I find this behavior strange and I cannot find any information in the documentation about that. 
This is about the nested forms, CVA and validation. 

I have a nested form structure:
- form container (not CVA, it contains CVA form controls)
- parent form (CVA) appended to the form container âï¸ 
- child form (CVA) appended to the parent form âï¸ 

Only the child form has a _required_ validator attached. I have also a button attached to the form container which should be disabled if the form (in the form container) is invalid. The problem is that the form container is valid, although the parent form and its child are invalid. 

Once I attach any validator to the parent form, the invalid event will be propagated to the form container. I'm not sure if it's a bug but I would expect that if the both forms are invalid (parent and child), the status should be also propagated to the form container and it's not. It's only propagated once the parent form has a validator attached. 

I prepared a stackblitz so that you can reproduce the issue. I would be very grateful if you could comment on that.

## ð¬ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-hhfydn
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Form status is not correctly propagated in the nested CVA forms" (#38991)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): iteratively parse interpolations
Issues.Body:
This patch refactors the interpolation parser to do so iteratively
rather than using a regex. Doing so prepares us for supporting granular
recovery on poorly-formed interpolations, for example when an
interpolation does not terminate (`{{ 1 + 2`) or is not terminated
properly (`{{ 1 + 2 {{ 2 + 3 }}`).

Part of #38596

Issues.Title: ContentChildren query lags in change detection when wrapped by template
Issues.Body:
# ð bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core probably ### Is this a regression? No, the issue was present at least since version 7 ### Description When your component has `ng-template` in its content for later instantiation and inside that template there's a list of items â you can query those children with `ContentChildren` once you instantiate the template. However change detection in them lags a cycle. ## ð¬ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-content-children-query-bug ## ð Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
10
**Anything else relevant?** In the reproduction Stackblitz, type a short string into input. This string is then broken into chars and spread into a list of DIVs with a 2 seconds delay. You can even see that "content checked" is printed to console when the list updates. However the `QueryList` of children is not refreshed. Also note that I had to wrap `setInterval` into `runOutsideAngular`. Otherwise it would create a tick that refreshes the query, even though both components are `OnPush`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ContentChildren query lags in change detection when wrapped by template" (#38976)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support package references in styles & scripts options
Issues.Body:
The browser builder's `styles` and `scripts` options now support using a package name in the path when specifying a style or script.  This removes the need to use a relative path to the node modules directory in these options.  This provides support for Yarn PnP as well as reducing the complexity of the options especially for monorepo setups.  Relatively located files will take precedence over packages if they exist.  This precedence provides backwards compatibility with existing configurations.

Before :
`"styles": ["../node_modules/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css"]`

After:
`"styles": ["bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css"]`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support package references in styles & scripts options" (#18879)

Issues.Title: Architect-cli, running serve target results in Data path "" should NOT have additional properties(_).
Issues.Body:
# ð Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ x ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... This bug is a regression. It looks like it is related to the refactoring to get ready for TS 4 (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/a85ba990eb9482e630ba78b6b8417edeb1499b21?branch=a85ba990eb9482e630ba78b6b8417edeb1499b21&diff=unified#diff-b2c222e0f78a5c4cf888115c56457e2dR87). In particular a change to this line: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blame/a85ba990eb9482e630ba78b6b8417edeb1499b21/packages/angular_devkit/architect_cli/bin/architect.ts#L87 ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... When running a serve target through the architect cli, it results in a schema validation error "Data path "" should NOT have additional properties(_)." Tracing through the code, it looks like the validation error was caused by the build options schema. It looks like minimalist npm library introduces an extra _ property when parsing args and those args are passed directly as build options for the serve target. In the refactor commit mentioned above, it looks like the code changed from `delete argv['_']` to `argv['_']=[]`, this looks to be the source of the problem. I did try reverting the line back to delete and the serve worked as expected. This could affect other targets, it just manifested under the serve target for me. ## ð¬ Minimal Reproduction To reproduce, create new project `> ng new cli-bug` Install architect-cli `> npm install @angular-devkit/architect-cli --save-dev` modify `package.json` to run architect cli instead of angular cli. ``` { "name": "cli-bug", "version": "0.0.0", "scripts": { "ng": "ng", "start": "architect cli-bug:serve", "build": "architect cli-bug:build", "test": "architect cli-bug:test", "lint": "architect cli-bug:lint", "e2e": "ng e2e" }, "private": true, "dependencies": { "@angular/animations": "~10.1.3", "@angular/common": "~10.1.3", "@angular/compiler": "~10.1.3", "@angular/core": "~10.1.3", "@angular/forms": "~10.1.3", "@angular/platform-browser": "~10.1.3", "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~10.1.3", "@angular/router": "~10.1.3", "rxjs": "~6.6.0", "tslib": "^2.0.0", "zone.js": "~0.10.2" }, "devDependencies": { "@angular-devkit/architect-cli": "^0.1001.3", "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~0.1001.3", "@angular/cli": "~10.1.3", "@angular/compiler-cli": "~10.1.3", "@types/jasmine": "~3.5.0", "@types/jasminewd2": "~2.0.3", "@types/node": "^12.11.1", "codelyzer": "^6.0.0", "jasmine-core": "~3.6.0", "jasmine-spec-reporter": "~5.0.0", "karma": "~5.0.0", "karma-chrome-launcher": "~3.1.0", "karma-coverage-istanbul-reporter": "~3.0.2", "karma-jasmine": "~4.0.0", "karma-jasmine-html-reporter": "^1.5.0", "protractor": "~7.0.0", "ts-node": "~8.3.0", "tslint": "~6.1.0", "typescript": "~4.0.2" } } ``` run start via: `> npm run start` ## ð¥ Exception or Error

Issues.Title: ng update on windows fails when cli version wants to preinstall | loader.js | Cannot find module
Issues.Body:
# ð Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ x ] update ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 6, 7, partially in 8 (depend on the cli version) ### Description A user directory on windows is 'C:\Users\Firstname Lastname\...' - what mean it includes a whitespace between the first and last name. When the given project has not the latest cli version installed, a temporary install happen of the lastes cli version to use it for ng update. Then the following error happen (I holde it generic by using "Firstname Lastname": ``` $ ng update The installed local Angular CLI version is older than the latest stable version. Installing a temporary version to perform the update. Installing packages for tooling via npm. Installed packages for tooling via npm. internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1083 throw err; ^ Error: Cannot find module 'C:\Users\Firstname' at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1080:15) at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:923:27) at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (internal/modules/run_main.js:72:12) at internal/main/run_main_module.js:17:47 { code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND', requireStack: [] } ``` ## ð¬ Minimal Reproduction Have a windows system where the user name uses a whitespace (like "Firstname Lastname" or "John Doe") and an Angular project that has not the latest cli installed. Run `ng update`. ## ð¥ Exception or Error 

$ ng update
The installed local Angular CLI version is older than the latest stable version.
Installing a temporary version to perform the update.
Installing packages for tooling via npm.
Installed packages for tooling via npm.
internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1083
  throw err;
  ^

Error: Cannot find module 'C:\Users\Firstname'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:1080:15)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:923:27)
    at Function.executeUserEntryPoint [as runMain] (internal/modules/run_main.js:72:12)
    at internal/main/run_main_module.js:17:47 {
  code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND',
  requireStack: []
}
## ð Your Environment

Then with the lastest version `ng update` always works. It is the problem with the mechanism to preinstall the lastes version on `ng update` command. I also tried to route the global node_modules to a different folder. That works for all global packages, but not for that command. It will always use the users directory.

Issues.Body:
<!--ððððððððððððððððððððððððððððððð

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

# ð Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- âï¸edit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [x] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
<!-- âï¸--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
The command `ng serve` currently does not generate service worker files.
It may be because in the past it was not possible to register service workers in non SSL sites.
There is now a exception to that, all `http://localhost` or `http://127.x.y.z` addresses do work (at least in Chrome)
This was already shortly discussed in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16883#issuecomment-650178791 but only the generation for `ng build --watch` was implemented.
`ng serve` & serve-ssr do not generate these files.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- âï¸--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
Generate the needed service worker files in `@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server` & `@nguniversal/builders:ssr-dev-server`

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- âï¸--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
Build the universal server & run that without serve-ssr, which is really cumbersome in development

Issues.Title: Lazy-loaded circular dependent components break live-reload
Issues.Body:
# ð Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 9.x ### Description In a specific scenario, changes to component code (template, styles, ts) result in erroneous js and an exception in the browser: `ReferenceError: Cannot access 'AComponent' before initialization`. In another scenario, a component stops rendering right after a given change in the template. See video for details. This happens in the following scenario: * Routing is used * Affected components are lazy-loaded * Components are circular dependent, i.e. imaine a tree-like data-structure, where nodes have child-nodes of the same type * Components are not directly but indirectly nested: a -> b -> c -> a -> b -> c -> a Changing _anything_ (e.g. a color in the styles) bricks the live-reloaded app. ## ð¬ Minimal Reproduction Repo: https://github.com/scheja/repro-app (Basic app, generated with `ng new --routing`) Start with `ng serve`, go to `http://localhost:4200/lazy`, then start editing e.g. `src/app/lazy/c/c.component.html` and watch what happens. Quick screen recording: https://youtu.be/d7Ch0pEPtNQ ## ð¥ Exception or Error ReferenceError: Cannot access 'AComponent' before initialization ## ð Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 10.1.3
Node: 14.10.1
OS: darwin x64

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- âï¸edit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [x] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
The tool parses imported third party modules in node_modules folder too and there is no way to exclude directories from parsing. For example:

create an new app
`ng new repro-app`

install a third party module
`npm @ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap`

import this module in the app.module.ts


```
import { NgbModule } from '@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap';
...
imports: [
    ...
      NgbModule
  ]
...

```
run xi18n
`ng xi18n --output-path src/locale --i18n-locale=de`

look in the generated messages.xlf

```
<trans-unit id="ngb.alert.close" datatype="html">
	<source>Close</source>
	<context-group purpose="location">
		<context context-type="sourcefile">node_modules/@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap/alert/alert.d.ts</context>
		<context context-type="linenumber">3</context>
	</context-group>
</trans-unit>
```

As you cas see the file contains translation units from a third party module although we don,t use it in our templates.

### Describe the solution you'd like

A command line parameter --exclude=path/one,path/two will solve my problem. Alternatively (or at once) the parameter --include=path/one, path/two will be helpful. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I could postprocess the messages.xlf with a custom tool to remove unwanted translation units.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Exclude directories from "ng xi18n"" (#18885)

Issues.Title: feat(migrations): reuse CDK migrations for our libraries
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Concerning the internal migration framework in src/cdk/schematics/ng-update/{data|migrations}:
We would love to be able to reuse this for our library, however some migrations specifically check for @angular/cdk or @angular/material (e.g. ClassNamesMigration => isMaterialImportDeclaration).
Would it be possible/acceptable to make the packages configurable?


#### Use Case

This would massively simplify the migration implementation of our component libraries.

Issues.Title: bug(MatRadioGroup): Cannot use a <mat-radio-group> inside a <mat-form-field>
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-czttdw
 
#### Expected Behavior

I want to be able to use a **mat-radio-group** inside a **mat-form-field**:

```
   <mat-form-field>
    <mat-radio-group formControlName="selectedValue">
        <mat-radio-button value="male">male</mat-radio-button>
        <mat-radio-button value="female">female</mat-radio-button>
    </mat-radio-group> 
  </mat-form-field>

```

In the linked StackBlitz, I have also added a **mat-select** inside a **mat-form-field**; this works correctly, and this is how I would expect **mat-radio-group** to work, too:

```
  <mat-form-field>
    <mat-label>Favorite food</mat-label>
    <mat-select formControlName="selectedValue">
      <mat-option *ngFor="let food of foods" [value]="food.value">
        {{food.viewValue}}
      </mat-option>
    </mat-select>
  </mat-form-field>
```

#### Actual Behavior

The radio buttons do not work; in the browser console this error is displayed:

> preview-29b0f46fcc27b310236ab.js:1 ERROR Error: mat-form-field must contain a MatFormFieldControl.
    at getMatFormFieldMissingControlError (form-field-errors.ts:21)
    at MatFormField._validateControlChild (form-field.ts:542)
    at MatFormField.ngAfterContentInit (form-field.ts:320)
    at callProviderLifecycles (provider.ts:563)
    at callElementProvidersLifecycles (provider.ts:542)
    at callLifecycleHooksChildrenFirst (provider.ts:530)
    at checkAndUpdateView (view.ts:376)
    at callViewAction (view.ts:626)
    at execComponentViewsAction (view.ts:570)
    at checkAndUpdateView (view.ts:381)

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.1.3
- CDK/Material: 10.2.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatRadioGroup): Cannot use a <mat-radio-group> inside a <mat-form-field>" (#20650)

Issues.Title: fix(material/select): option active styling not removed when value is changed programmatically
Issues.Body:
If an option is selected by the user and the value is changed programmatically afterwards, we weren't removing the active state from the previous option. This seems to be a regression from #19970.

These changes resolve the issue and preserve the fix from #19970 by resetting the active styling manually.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/select): option active styling not removed when value is changed programmatically" (#20649)

Issues.Title: bug(DRAG&DROP): The cdkDropList should be accessible when moving an element
Issues.Body:
I have a kanban board (like Trello) with columns that are collapsable. If a column is collapsed and I hover it when I move a card, I make it uncollaplle. However, at that point the `cdkDropListContainer` does not allow me to "drop" the card from within. 

Initially the `cdkDropList` element was "masked" with an `*ngIf` directive, I replaced it with the `hidden` attribute and then I tested with just a css style to set the size to 0 but none of these solutions worked. The result is always the same.

How is this done? How do I do it? 

I use : "@angular/cdk": "^10.0.1".

Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(DRAG&DROP): The cdkDropList should be accessible when moving an element" (#20647)

These changes clean up such usages by having a protected method for retrieving the harness root element that can be overwritten when necessary.

Issues.Title: FocusMonitor TypeError: Cannot read property 'remove' of undefined (classlist)
Issues.Body:
While using @angular/cdk ~10.2.2 and @angular/material ^10.2.2 I keep encountering the following error:
```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'remove' of undefined
    at FocusMonitor._toggleClass (a11y.js:1928)
    at FocusMonitor._setClasses (a11y.js:1957)
    at FocusMonitor.stopMonitoring (a11y.js:1897)
    at MatTooltip.ngOnDestroy (tooltip.js:249)
    at executeOnDestroys (core.js:9070)
    at cleanUpView (core.js:8992)
    at destroyViewTree (core.js:8796)
    at destroyLView (core.js:8945)
    at RootViewRef.destroy (core.js:9679)
    at ComponentRef$1.destroy (core.js:22234)
    at resolvePromise (zone.js:1215)
    at resolvePromise (zone.js:1165)
    at zone.js:1277
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone.js:407)
    at Object.onInvokeTask (core.js:27418)
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone.js:406)
    at Zone.runTask (zone.js:179)
    at drainMicroTaskQueue (zone.js:583)
```

The error occurs when I navigate from one page to the other. I noticed the MatTooltip class in the stacktrace, and I'd like to note that while many of the components on the page use tooltips, none were active during the time of navigation (this was instigated by a div with routerLink inside a MatMenu).
The error appears to completely break the website, leaving only a background color. Refreshing the page successfully completes the navigation. 
If any further information is needed, please let me know.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "FocusMonitor TypeError: Cannot read property 'remove' of undefined (classlist)" (#20632)
